thread.title: Ben Bradshaw calls on Devon Tories to break ranks and defend democracy in Commons Brexit vote

author: Phil Goodwin
title: Ben Bradshaw calls on Devon Tories to break ranks and defend democracy in Commons Brexit vote
text:
News Ben Bradshaw calls on Devon Tories to break ranks and defend democracy in Commons Brexit vote Critics say the Bill gives the Executive too much control and represents the biggest power grab since the time of Henry VIII Share Ben Bradhsaw after increasing his majority in May Share Comments 
Exeter’s Ben Bradshaw has called on Devon’s 10 Tory MPs to put democracy before party and break ranks in a key Commons vote. 
MPs will tonight have the first chance to vote on the Government’s Brexit Bill, which transfers European Union rules and regulations into domestic laws. 
Labour will vote against the legislation, arguing so-called “Henry VIII” powers in the Bill allowing ministers to alter laws without full parliamentary scrutiny amount to a “power-grab”. 
Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and Brexit Secretary David Davis have warned that opposing the bill would result in a “disorderly and chaotic” departure from the bloc in March 2019. 
The warnings from the senior Cabinet ministers are aimed at both wavering Labour MPs – particularly from Leave-backing seats – and Remain-supporting Tories. Ben Bradshaw, former Culture Secretary 
Mr Bradshaw says Conservatives should put part allegiances aside to protect democracy. 
He told Devonlive.com: “I hope very much that given the strong criticism by a lot of Conservative MPs of this power grab by the Government that they will work with Labour and other opposition parties in parliament but I fear they won’t. 
“Brexit was supposed to be about bringing power back to parliament but this bill constitutes the biggest power grab by the executive and the diminution of parliament since Henry VIII and should be opposed by all democrats. 
“If the Tories don’t break ranks tonight I hope very much they will support amendments to improve the bill and ensure that our elected parliament is at the centre of discussions and decision making on one of the most important issues our country has faced for 50 years.”

Jeremy Corbyn has called on all Labour MPs to follow him in voting down the flagship Bill. 
Downing Street has said it is confident of victory in the crunch second reading vote on the EU (Withdrawal) Bill, expected in the early hours of Tuesday after a debate stretching up to midnight. 
Theresa May’s fragile grip on power in the Commons, relying on the votes of the DUP for a majority, could be boosted by an estimated dozen Labour rebels prepared to defy Jeremy Corbyn’s orders. 
Privately, opponents do not expect Tory rebels to line up against the leadership tonight. 
Those unhappy with the Bill will seek to secure concessions through amendments with any protest expected to come during the second reading and committee stages. 
Torbay MP Kevin Foster said Labour's calls were a "smoke screen" designed to "bog down" the progress of the Bill. 
The Conservative said there were enough checks and balances in place, from the both Houses and the courts to prevent any abuse of democracy. 
He said Mr Bradshaw should "be honest" and admit that he is simply trying to frustrate Brexit. 
"I would have a lot more respect for Ben if he were more honest that he wants to bog down parliament and hope Brexit won't happen," he added. 
"MPs and the House of Lords have a veto over Statutory Instruments - legislation can also be challenged in the courts and struck down. 
"There has been a referendum, whatever MP's view might be and we need to get on with the job of making sure we have a functioning statute book."
